channel.title: ASF JIRA
channel.description: This file is an XML representation of an issue

item.title: [HBASE-16179] Fix compilation errors when building hbase-spark against Spark 2.0
item.description:
I tried building hbase-spark module against Spark-2.0 snapshot and got the following compilation errors:

http://pastebin.com/bg3w247a

Some Spark classes such as DataTypeParser and Logging are no longer accessible to downstream projects.

hbase-spark module should not depend on such classes.
item.summary: Fix compilation errors when building hbase-spark against Spark 2.0

status.description: A patch for this issue has been uploaded to JIRA by a contributor.

comments.comment:
presumably the fix here will aim for still working with Spark 1.6?

Is spark-2.0 still keeping Scala 2.10 around?

Scala 2.10 support is maintained:

https://amplab.cs.berkeley.edu/jenkins/view/Spark%20QA%20Compile/job/SPARK-master-COMPILE-sbt-SCALA-2.10/

Let's see how hard it is to keep hbase-spark module working against Spark 1.6.1
a jenkins job maintained on some non-ASF service doesn't answer the question. Is there a DISCUSS or VOTE thread somewhere, a roadmap, or a compatibility guide (like we have for java versions)?

See this thread:

http://search-hadoop.com/m/q3RTtL7Wg54KKcD&subj=Re+Discuss+commit+to+Scala+2+10+support+for+Spark+2+x+lifecycle

(here's that same thread on lists.apache: https://s.apache.org/BjIY )

The discussion seems kind of back and forth, to me. I think it says they're keeping it in 2.0 at least. Let's work under that presumption and we can ask them for clarification.

Looks like HBase 2.0 release would come out several months after Spark 2.0 release.
Do we have to introduce shim layer so that hbase-spark module compiles against both Spark 1.6 and 2.0 ?

I suspect we need a dev@ discussion about what versions of Spark we want to support in what versions of HBase. I still expect that spark support will get in to HBase branch-1, and I'd expect that we should work with both Spark 1.6 and Spark 2.0. I'm less sure about Scala versions.

w.r.t. Logging, we can clone a copy and put it in hbase-spark module.

For other Spark classes, we may need a shim layer.

The Logging should never have been used - take a look at this commit to the cassandra project for an example of how we can build an internal Logging trait.

https://github.com/datastax/spark-cassandra-connector/commit/98d610e866463a15e91f7e4a967e09ab338aa330

With patch v0, here are the compilation errors:

http://pastebin.com/BA1czzdT

Made some progress:

http://pastebin.com/zg3nSUmL
Previous patch v1 missed the new file.
Is there a way to compile HBase with Spark 2.0 without hitting this issue ?

With patch v4, tests in hbase-spark pass against Spark 2.0 release.

Still need to figure out how to support Spark 1.6 at the same time.

To handle incompatibilities between Spark 1.6 and 2.0, one approach is to introduce new modules which contain code for Spark 1.6 and 2.0, respectively.

Sean Busbey:
What do you think ?
you mean a compat shim like we do for hadoop stuff? or you mean two entirely different implementations?

An hbase-spark-compat module would be introduced.
hbase-spark1.6-compat provides implementation for Spark 1.6
hbase-spark2.0-compat provides implementation for Spark 2.0
yeah that sounds good to me.
what about the scala binary compat issue? Can we keep Scala out of the shim module and then use scala 2.10 for 1.6 and scala 2.11 for 2.0?
Patch v5 adds DataTypeParser trait which can serve as the basis for multi-module support.
Since Scala 2.10 is supported by Spark 2.0, it is separate dimension.

So you'd like us to just mandate Scala 2.10 for both 1.6 and 2.0, right?

Reading through the threads when dev@spark talks about scala versions I got the sense that Scala 2.10 won't be long for the 2.y line. When that time comes, what would we do? I'm not necessarily asking that we address this now, just want to know that we've thought of a general approach to supportability. We haven't taken a stance as a community yet on support timelines for Scala versions, but I'd expect we'd treat them similar to JDK versions, which would means we'd keep a Scala 2.10 based Spark 2 module for the remainder of HBase 2.y.

Patch v7 adds two modules:

hbase-spark-compat for Spark 2.0 (default)
hbase-spark1.6-compat for Spark 1.6

You can build for Spark 1.6 by using:

mvn package -DskipTests -Dspark.profile=1.6

To build against Scala 2.11 :

mvn package -DskipTests -Dscala.version=2.11.8

Review on v7.

This fails for me:

 

mvn clean dependency:tree 

mvn clean dependency:tree -Dspark.profile=1.6

This works


mvn clean dependency:tree -Dspark.profile=2.0

hbase-spark/pom.xml

  • currently no profile is activated – both say !spark.profile. You want default with !spark.profile and the othres with actual values the values – 1.6 and 2.0. Look at how hadoop.profile is handled.
  • Based on sean's comments can you make the default scala 2.11? We don't have to update as much going forward.

hbasetablescanrdd

  • why is the "//with Logging" comment there? Remove?

pom.xml

  • consider calling the modules hbase-spark1.6-compat and hbase-spark2.0-compat instead of hbase-spark1.6-compat and hbase-spark-compat. This way when new spark versions come out and we need do a ship, it will be obvious what to do.

DataTypeParserWrapper

  • add comments about why this exists (e.g. necessary for spark2.0, not present in 1.6 etc)

Logging

  • add comments saying why this is present instead of using the spark1.6 Logging class.

nits: fix space/tabs issues in hbase-spark/pom.xml
can we work it so both modules build all the time? if we have to build each individually we'll be making the build process for our RMs harder.

Based on sean's comments can you make the default scala 2.11? We don't have to update as much going forward.

This would mean when we publish a release with the module, we'll be supporting Spark 1.6 on Scala 2.11? We might want to see if the Scala community has any kind of survey data on how common this is; I would have presumed 2.10 would be more common on Spark 1.6.

can we work it so both modules build all the time

To build two modules we would need another module to use Spark 1.6 (the non-default) compat.

Patch v8 addresses Jonathan's comments.

I leave Scala version at 2.11 since by the time hbase 2.0 is released that would be the dominant Scala version in use.

I did a quick pass on v8 and several of the items I mentioned weren't addressed yet. (tabs issues, dependency:tree with -Dspark.profile=1.6 still fails for me). I'll take another look on the next rev.
'dependency:tree' depends on Spark 1.6 Compatibility being installed first.
Patch v9 removes tabs from hbase-spark/pom.xml.

comments on v9:

  • In JavaHBaseContext.scala 
    
-    def fn = (it: Iterator[T], conn: Connection) =>

-      asScalaIterator(

-        f.call((asJavaIterator(it), conn)).iterator()

-      )

+    def fn = (it: Iterator[T], conn: Connection) => {

+      val iter = f.call(asJavaIterator(it), conn)

+      if (iter.isInstanceOf[Iterable[R]]) {

+        asScalaIterator(iter.asInstanceOf[Iterable[R]].iterator())

+      } else {

+        asScalaIterator(iter)

+      }

+    }

why do you need the if instanceOf? f.call will always return an iterator, isn't that all you need? I thought you'd just remove the .iterator() in the original version.

  • In HBaseTableScanRDD.scala you are removing the mixed in Logging trait. But there are still calls to logDebug etc. How does that work? Seems like its using the logging from within RDD, but I thought the scala compiler would complain about escaped visibility scope or something. I would think you'd need to either remove the calls to logDebug, or do something like this to use the hbase Logging trait:

class HBaseTableScanRDD ... {

  val logger = new Object with Logging

  ...

  logger.logDebug(...)

}

I'd be curious if it really does work like this, it would mean spark is leaking something it doesn't intend to.

  • I would think that the spark & scala version properties in hbase-spark/pom.xml would be set inside the profiles, but I admit I don't spend a ton of time following the exact pom setup, so maybe its fine.
  • a couple of commented out bits that should be removed

HBaseTableScanRDD extends RDD which has:


  ) extends Serializable with Logging {

So HBaseTableScanRDD uses Spark's Logging.

w.r.t. the spark & scala version properties, since hbase-spark1.6-compat and hbase-spark2.0-compat modules are built first, the versions need to be specified.

I found one commented out import in Utils.scala. It is removed in the next patch.

ah, sorry I forgot that you were making JavaHBaseContext.scala work with both versions of spark. I'd at least include a comment to that effect. As is, it chooses the branch at runtime, as opposed to choosing which one at compile time by having two different implementations which get chosen by the profile. (Doesn't really matter to me which one you do, just noting the difference.) A minor nit, if you are going to stick w/ doing it at runtime, I'd write it with pattern matching (this may also fix the compile errors w/ 1.6):


def fn = (it: Iterator[T], conn: Connection) => {

  asScalaIterator(

    // the return type is different in spark 1.x & 2.x, we handle both cases

    f.call(asJavaIterator(it), conn) match {

      // spark 1.x

      case iterable: Iterable[R] => iterable.iterator()

      // spark 2.x

      case iterator: Iterator[R] => iterator

    }

  )

}

on HBaseTableScanRDD – I am surprised it can use the logging methods from spark's internal Logging, thought that was against scala's scoping rules. But I guess I was wrong if it works.
Patch v10 adopts Imran's comment above.

Stephen Yuan Jiang:
This should be included in the alpha release.

Can you take a look ?
Ted Yu you haven't addressed my concerns nor my suggestion of a feature branch as a compromise position. To be clear, I'm prepared to binding veto inclusion in the alpha release of HBase 2.0.

Wouldn't the hadoop-3.0 profile pose the same burden on RM ?

Can you clarify ?

1) Problems with other in-flight tickets aren't relevant to issues with this one

2) this change impacts users down stream of us. AFAIK, a downstream user who wants to run our module on Spark 2.0 needs different jars than someone who wants to run our module on Spark 1.6.

3) If you believe the current Hadoop 3 profile requires us to do multiple build steps to generate different convenience binaries, please do file a jira about it or comment on where ever that work is happening. If our current use of hadoop is only source compatible and not binary compatible for use with supported Hadoop 2s and supported Hadoop 3s, that's a problem. (Though AFAIK we haven't officially adopted a position of supporting Hadoop 3.)

As Jonathan outlined in this thread:
http://search-hadoop.com/m/YGbb2Dy4T62T3n1&subj=Re+Hadoop+3+x+profile+working+for+hbase+2+0+Re+HBASE+2+0+

Making Hadoop 3.x profile work for hbase 2.0 would be done in milestones.

This JIRA is about making compilation pass based on Spark 2.0
In my interpretation, this corresponds to milestone 1 in the above thread.

Ted Yu, for the hadoop 3 changes, even though there are two profiles, there is only one set of code and one set of hbase-server binaries that could be used against either hadoop 2.x or hadoop 3.x. The profiles simplify unit testing does not require separate binaries to run against hadoop 2 or hadoop3.

The discussion here is about having two different modules and binaries – one for spark 1.x and one for spark 2.x. If you can you make it one binary the two cases are similar. If you have to make different binaries for each version, it is very different from a release manager's point of view.

Here is one more dimension to consider:
code compiled with Scalac 2.10 won't run correctly against Scala 2.11, and vice versa. 2.10 and 2.11 are binary incompatible.
Right, there was discussion earlier in this JIRA about what version(s) of Scala we'd be shipping support for out of the box.

Using reflection is another approach.

However, implementation for org.apache.spark.sql.types.DataType has changed between 1.6 and 2.0
It is not prudent to expose DataType in build artifact if the artifact is shared across Spark releases.

Here is a related thread for a poll on dropping support for Scala 2.10 :

http://search-hadoop.com/m/Spark/q3RTtwK7l612MKAk?subj=Re+Straw+poll+dropping+support+for+things+like+Scala+2+10
Patch v12 is rebased on current master.

With patch v15, there would be two jars generated:


-rw-r--r--  1 tyu  staff  775422 Nov 16 14:39 ./hbase-spark/target/hbase-spark-2.0.2_2.11-2.0.0-SNAPSHOT.jar

-rw-r--r--  1 tyu  staff  769903 Nov 16 14:38 ./hbase-spark-scala-2.10/target/hbase-spark-2.0.2_2.10-2.0.0-SNAPSHOT.jar

hbase-spark-2.0.2_2.11-2.0.0-SNAPSHOT.jar is compiled against Spark 2.0.2 with Scala 2.11
hbase-spark-2.0.2_2.10-2.0.0-SNAPSHOT.jar is compiled against Spark 2.0.2 with Scala 2.10
I can add two more modules which would produce jars for Spark 1.6 based on Scala 2.10 and 2.11, respectively.
that sounds lovely, Ted Yu. thanks!
